results.title: The Vanished vikings. Part 1: Erik the Red
results.creator_credit: Gilbert Altschul Productions, Journal Films and Edwin Morrisby
results.brief_description: In 986 A.D. Erik the Red and his Vikings left Iceland and establish settlements in Greenland that were thought to be continuously occupied for 500 years before suddenly ceasing to exist. Traces Erik’s travels, using sagas as well as archaeological evidence. Suitable for upper primary and lower secondary levels.

results.title: The Van
results.creator_credit: BBC, Deadly Films, Lynda Myles and Stephen Frears
results.brief_description: Set during the 1989 World Cup season when Ireland’s national identity is intricately wrapped up in its sporting success, “The Van” follows the relationship of lifelong friends, Brendan (Bimbo) and Larry. Larry, long time unemployed and living on welfare, finds his professional friend Bimbo joining the ranks of the unemployed when he is retrenched. With the help of a dodgy associate, Bimbo purchases a dilapidated van and miraculously cleans it up to create the modest business enterprise of Bimbo’s Burgers. He asks his best mate Larry to work for him, and soon Larry’s daughter Diane and vegetarian son Kevin begin work with them to cater for the soccer, beach and concert crowds. As the pressure of working long hours, meeting stringent health regulations and Bimbo’s dismay at Larry’s work ethic weighs on them, Larry and Bimbo push the boundaries of their relationship, forcing them to choose between being partners and being friends. With a soundtrack by Eric Clapton, “The Van” is the final chapter in Roddy Doyle’s Barrytown trilogy. Cast includes Colm Meaney, Donal O’Kelly, Neili Conroy and Ger Ryan.
results.creator_credit_for_label: BBC, Deadly Films, Lynda Myles and Stephen Frears

results.title: The Van
results.creator_credit: Crown International Pictures, Paul Lewis and Sam Grossman
results.brief_description: Bobby is a young man, just graduated from High School, who imagines himself in a sexual situation with every attractive woman that he encounters. The reality is that Bobby is single, but his investment in new wheels brings with it the potential for real sexual experience. The van in question is a souped up vehicle complete with waterbed, plush interior and mirrors on the ceiling. Bobby’s investment in the van is threatened when a friend in trouble desperately needs his car loan repayment money. Simultaneously Bobby falls for a local girl, who challenges Bobby’s desire to sleep with a bevy of women. This film often skips into dream mode, whence the audience witnesses the sexual fantasy of various characters as they gaze upon a particular scene or person. This film is in part a curio from the 1970s that documents a car culture fetish and a male desire to assuage ego with sexual experiences. Features Danny De Vito in a minor role.

results.title: The value of winning
results.brief_description:
To combat a declining number of players in the local community and to add talent to their team, many football clubs are buying in star players to boost their chance of winning a flag.

Thank you to Graham Campbell, Rob Barrett, and Merv Neagle. Premiership flag footage by John Teasdale, used with permission. All still images reproduced courtesy of Balranald Football Club.

TRANSCRIPT

[CROWD CHEERING]

GRAHAM “JOCK” CAMPBELL: We’ve won three premierships. And really, it looks like it’s a cycle of about every 10 years that someone decides, well, it’s time that we had another go, so. I’ve been involved in the three premierships that we have won and involved again at the moment. Balranald’s a town of 1,400 people. Virtually impossible to keep the young people here. So it makes it pretty hard that way.

[CROWD CHEERING]

-To get the success— and I mean, the great form of success— you’ve got to bring some players in. And I’m not being derogative to our boys, but we just haven’t got the overall talent and the numbers of talented players to win a flag.

[CROWD CHEERING]

All Central Murray clubs would be spending, at the moment— the majority of them, anyway, the successful ones, say, 6 or 8 of the top 12, would spend in excess of $100,000 a year on players alone.

[CROWD CHEERING]

GRAHAM “JOCK” CAMPBELL: It’s not unreasonable to pay players, $700, $800, $900, or $1,000 a game to be competitive. I have contributed large sums of money. But we’ve certainly done our homework. We’ve gone around metro Melbourne and Mildura and hand-picked the players that we reckoned wood do the job.

[PLAYERS SHOUTING]

MERV NEAGLE: I think after the ‘94 Premiership, this club won 14 games in 10 years. You know, I mean, and you get sick of it. You don’t want to go along and the players get sick of it. The all the supporters get sick of it.

So when all of a sudden, they decided, OK let’s have another crack at it, it’s just like a breath of fresh air, isn’t it? OK, we’ve got a good side. We’re going to win. Let’s go to the footy.

And the whole town on a Saturday when the team plays away— like we went to Tooleybuc on Saturday. You could have fired a gun up the Main Street of this town and you wouldn’t have hit anyone. There’s just a different hype around the place when your football side’s winning. That’s how important it is to the town, you know?

So at the moment, all’s— well, we were runners-up last year. And hopefully we have a side good enough to go one step better this year.

[CROWD CHEERING]

ROB BARRETT: A lot of people don’t like what we do. And I mean, that’s the jealousy thing comes into it. And yeah, each time that we’ve one a premiership, there’s been money involved. So you do tend to get that. Oh, well, they bought a premiership. Yeah, there’s a fair bit of feeling comes about. I mean, yeah, you talk about these country teams and country footy clubs, money’s a big thing.

[CROWD CHEERING]

[CROWD CHEERING]

results.title: The Valley revisited
results.creator_credit: Movietonenews and Twentieth Century-Fox Film Corporation
results.brief_description: The Tennessee Valley Authority was the largest project undertaken by President Roosevelt’s Works Project Administration, transforming a malarial floodplain into a prosperous agricultural region and improving the living and working conditions for those who lived on the plain. President Kennedy’s vulnerability at his address when he visited the Project for the 30th anniversary celebrations on 18 May 1963 prefigured his assassination six months later.

results.title: The Valley of the Tennessee
results.creator_credit: United States. Office of War Information and Alexander Hammid
results.brief_description: A moving and human story of the work of the TVA in rescuing the people of the Tennessee Valley from floods and erosion. The river’s energy was running to waste, and floods were frequent and tragic; the once-good soil was deteriorating from erosion and over-cropping; the farmers struggled on in poverty and hopelessness. The Tennessee Valley Authority was created to build dams, to control the floods, to use the water for irrigation, hydro-electricity and navigation, to restore the Valley to prosperity again. Most of the farmers, sunk in poverty and despair, proved difficult to help, but gradually the younger ones among them were won over, first to interest, and then to enthusiasm and co-operation. As a result of years of work, and increasing self help and experiment on the part of the farmers working with TVA, the great Valley of the Tennessee, larger in area that the United Kingdom, has been restored in some measure to fertility and prosperity. This film is remarkable for its treatment of larger issues through the reactions of individuals-in particular, a child, a young farmer, and an old farmer-and the economy and insight of its visuals. Script by May Sarton. Photographed by Peter Glushanok.

results.title: The Valley is ours
results.creator_credit: Stanley Hawes, John Heyer and Australian National Film Board
results.brief_description: This classic documentary celebrates the variety of activities the Murray River and the surrounding district sustains: from agriculture to timber, fishing to mining, fruit picking to shipbuilding. There is a special focus on the optimistic spirit of the people of the region as they overcome problems of erosion, bushfire and drought and makes a plea for further development, arguing that at least another million people could find happy homes in this fertile territory.

results.title: The Valley
results.brief_description: A before and after story of the pollution of the Ohio River Valley. The pollution included sewage, industrial waste and mining pollution. The controls: monitoring of the rivers conditions, and enforcement of regulations governing the disposal of waste material have contributed to the improvement of the area.

results.title: The Valley
results.creator_credit: Edward Street Films, Katherine Scholes and Roger Scholes
results.brief_description: Produced with the co-operation of the local community and World Vision Ethiopia staff in the Omo Valley, this film traces transformation of an area devastated by drought and land degradation into green and productive land, reversing the trend of environmental destruction and poverty.

results.title: The Valkyrie = Die Walkure
results.creator_credit: Metropolitan Opera, Peter Gelb, Brian Large and Phebe Berkowitz
results.brief_description: Includes guide in both English and German. The second installment of Wagner’s Ring des Nibelungen follows the tragic destiny og Brunnhilde, daughter of Wotan (Master of Valhalla). Sent by her father to murder Siegmund and Sieglinde, the twins borne to Wotan by a mortal, she is moved by the love she witnesses and disobbeys Wotan’s command. Wotan’s punishment is to hold Brunnhilde in a magic sleep, making her a defenceless prey for the first man who passes by and wakes her. Moved by his daughter’s plea for mercy, Wotan agrees to her request of being guarded in her sleep by a circle of flames that only a true and unrestrained hero can traverse to reach and awake her. See also: The Rhinegold (1) Siegfried (3) and Twilight of the Gods (4) of Wagner’s famous tetralogy.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Metropolitan Opera, Peter Gelb, Brian Large and Phebe Berkowitz
results.description: Includes guide in both English and German. The second installment of Wagner’s Ring des Nibelungen follows the tragic destiny og Brunnhilde, daughter of Wotan (Master of Valhalla). Sent by her father to murder Siegmund and Sieglinde, the twins borne to Wotan by a mortal, she is moved by the love she witnesses and disobbeys Wotan’s command. Wotan’s punishment is to hold Brunnhilde in a magic sleep, making her a defenceless prey for the first man who passes by and wakes her. Moved by his daughter’s plea for mercy, Wotan agrees to her request of being guarded in her sleep by a circle of flames that only a true and unrestrained hero can traverse to reach and awake her. See also: The Rhinegold (1) Siegfried (3) and Twilight of the Gods (4) of Wagner’s famous tetralogy.
